Issues.Title: Remove workarounds
Issues.Body:
Please review by commit. These are 3 additional changes related to WindowsDesktop SDK.

8ecabfc is to solve https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/12403 (currently has a workaround in SDK)
7baee74 is solve a simple mistake
f309b4b is moved due to dotnet/sdk@d21aaa5

Tested against _WPF-Samples\Graphics\Point_. And all SDK unit tests

SDK side change https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/12459
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove workarounds" (#3248)

Issues.Title: CroppedBitmap does not propagate underlaying SourceBitmap changes.
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.1
* Windows version: 10
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: Don't know
* Is this bug related specifically to tooling in Visual Studio (e.g. XAML Designer, Code editing, etc...)? No

 <!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->
 
 **Problem description:**

I am using an `System.Windows.Controls.Image` that has been bound to a `System.Windows.Media.Imaging.CroppedBitmap` using a `System.Windows.Media.Imaging.WriteableBitmap` as a source.

The WriteableBitmap contents are being rewritten several times per second.

If I bind the `WriteableBitmap` directly to the `Image`, the image onscreen is being updated correctly.

But if I wrap the `WriteableBitmap` with a `CroppedBitmap` and the latter is bound to the `Image`, the onscreen view is not being refreshed when I rewrite the writeable bitmap's contents.

This seems to indicate that changes on the `WriteableBitmap` are not propagated up the ladder to the `CroppedBitmap`

 
 **Actual behavior:**

The onscreen image is not updated when I rewrite the underlaying WriteableBitmap's content.
 
 **Expected behavior:**

The Image control accepts a BitmapSource as it's content source. It should play nice with **all** BitmapSource derived classes, and it should refresh the onscreen's view when the underlaying source of a CroppedBitmap is updated.

At first I thought this would be a feature request, but in truth, the inhability of CroppedBitmap to propagate changes of the underlaying BitmapSource essentially cripples CroppedBitmap for many many use cases.

Also, I consider that a CroppedBitmap wrapping another bitmap should behave exactly the same as the underlaying source bitmap, provided the cropping rectangle is of full size.  And this is not the case with WriteableBitmap when its pixels are rewritten.
 
 **Minimal repro:**

```c#
var writeable = new WriteableBitmap();
var cropped = new CroppedBitmap( writeable, new Int32Rect...);
var image = new Image();
image.Source = cropped;
// use image in a XAML for display
writeable.WritePixels(...);  // this should refresh image's onscreen view.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CroppedBitmap does not propagate underlaying SourceBitmap changes." (#3251)

Issues.Title: Add globbing support for WinUI
Issues.Body:
The WinUI team needs support for globbing support so that Visual Studio will not edit the .csproj whenever you add a .xaml file to the project. See this bug as a reference: https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/issues/2498

In following the same pattern as WPF, we can add a `UseWinUI` property that will pull in the `Microsoft.NET.WindowsDesktop.Sdk` and enable the globbing support.

If both `UseWinUI` and `UseWpf` are true, then the SDK can assume all xaml files are for WPF. The WinUI nuget will respect the use of `UseWpf` and not invoke the winui xaml compiler if that is the case. If only `UseWinUI` is true, then the SDK should not invoke PBT. Below is a table describing the different combinations and what should happen:

| UseWpf | UseWinUI | Xaml Compiler invoked |
|      :-:       |        :-:         |             :-:           |
|  `True`    |  `True`           | PBT                    |
|  `True`    |  `False`          | PBT                    |
|  `False`    |  `True`          | WinUI Compiler |
|  `False`    |  `False`         | neither |
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add globbing support for WinUI " (#3245)

Issues.Title: Disable per-build validation
Issues.Body: Reduces build time. SDL is now right nightly + on each build candidate. No need to keep running on a per-build basis.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Disable per-build validation" (#3236)

Issues.Title: wpf `FormatLine` api cause the wpfapp-hang[serious]
Issues.Body:
<!--This is just a template - feel free to delete any and all of it and replace as appropriate.-->

### Description
AS THE ISSUE SHOW:  [WPF APP will hang if the editor SyntaxHighlighting=python](https://github.com/icsharpcode/AvalonEdit/issues/241)
THE `System.Windows.Media.TextFormatting` . `FormatLine` cause a app-hang.
![I%I~LKA04`SA6@G~ Y P8A6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1876302/87317844-206d8b80-c55a-11ea-8c1e-25d3d92eeaa4.png)


<!--
* Please share a clear and concise description of the problem.
* Include minimal steps to reproduce the problem if possible. E.g.: the smallest possible code snippet; or a small repo to clone, with steps to run it.
* What behavior are you seeing, and what behavior would you expect?
  -->

### Configuration
 my work-pc  has the problem:
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
dotnetcore: 3.1.301 x64
but my home-pc work well:
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19041
dotnetcore: 3.1.301x64

somebody can help, beacuse this stops my work a little bit
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "wpf `FormatLine` api cause the wpfapp-hang[serious]" (#3246)

Issues.Title: Add SDL vars config file
Issues.Body: Enables post-build and nightly SDL verification, rather than within the build
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add SDL vars config file" (#3234)

Issues.Title: Why only after window.show() beem called, then we can get the handle of the window?
Issues.Body:
I wanna get the handle of a window, but i found that only after i called window.show(), then the handle is not null. I understand this is a lazy load strategy, but is there a way that once i create a new window instance, i can get the handle immediately. If not, do wpf will support in the future?

Thank you!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Why only after window.show() beem called, then we can get the handle of the window?" (#3235)
